template.template: Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent
template.name: Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent

item.name: CPU interrupt time
item.description: The Processor Information\% Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. This is an easy way to identify a potential hardware failure. This should never be higher than 20%.

item.name: Context switches per second
item.description: Context Switches/sec is the combined rate at which all processors on the computer are switched from one thread to another. Context switches occur when a running thread voluntarily relinquishes the processor, is preempted by a higher priority ready thread, or switches between user-mode and privileged (kernel) mode to use an Executive or subsystem service. It is the sum of Thread\\Context Switches/sec for all threads running on all processors in the computer and is measured in numbers of switches. There are context switch counters on the System and Thread objects. This counter displays the difference between the values observed in the last two samples, divided by the duration of the sample interval.

item.name: CPU privileged time
item.description: The Processor Information\% Privileged Time counter shows the percent of time that the processor is spent executing in Kernel (or Privileged) mode. Privileged mode includes services interrupts inside Interrupt Service Routines (ISRs), executing Deferred Procedure Calls (DPCs), Device Driver calls and other kernel-mode functions of the WindowsÂ® Operating System.

item.name: CPU user time
item.description: The Processor Information\% User Time counter shows the percent of time that the processor(s) is spent executing in User mode.

item.name: CPU queue length
item.description: The Processor Queue Length shows the number of threads that are observed as delayed in the processor Ready Queue and are waiting to be executed.

template.template: Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent
template.name: Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent

item.name: Cache bytes
item.description: Cache Bytes is the sum of the Memory\\System Cache Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Driver Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Code Resident Bytes, and Memory\\Pool Paged Resident Bytes counters. This counter displays the last observed value only; it is not an average.

item.name: Free system page table entries
item.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak or you running out of memory.

item.name: Memory page faults per second
item.description: Page Faults/sec is the average number of pages faulted per second. It is measured in number of pages faulted per second because only one page is faulted in each fault operation, hence this is also equal to the number of page fault operations. This counter includes both hard faults (those that require disk access) and soft faults (where the faulted page is found elsewhere in physical memory.) Most processors can handle large numbers of soft faults without significant consequence. However, hard faults, which require disk access, can cause significant delays.

item.name: Memory pages per second
item.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory pool non-paged
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the non-paged pool. This is an area of system memory for objects that cannot be written to disk but instead must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. There is a possible memory leak if the value is greater than 175MB (or 100MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2019 is recorded in the system event log.

template.template: Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent
template.name: Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent

discovery_rule.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of file systems of different types.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<5G or {Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Space used: {ITEM.VALUE3} of {ITEM.VALUE2} ({ITEM.VALUE1}), time left till full: < 24h. Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}. Second condition should be one of the following: - The disk free space is less than 5G. - The disk will be full in less than 24hours.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<10G or {Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Space used: {ITEM.VALUE3} of {ITEM.VALUE2} ({ITEM.VALUE1}), time left till full: < 24h. Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}. Second condition should be one of the following: - The disk free space is less than 10G. - The disk will be full in less than 24hours.

dependency.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
dependency.expression: {Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<5G or {Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)

Template Module Windows filesystems by Zabbix agent

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Windows physical disks by Zabbix agent:vfs.dev.util[PercentDiskTime.{#DEVNAME}].min(15m)}>{$VFS.DEV.UTIL.MAX.WARN}
trigger_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk is overloaded (util > {$VFS.DEV.UTIL.MAX.WARN}% for 15m)

item.name: Number of threads
item.description: The number of threads used by all running processes.

template.template: Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent
template.name: Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}"].avg(15m)}>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*{Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()} or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}"].avg(15m)}>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*{Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()}) and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()}>0
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}"].avg(15m)}<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*{Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()} and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}"].avg(15m)}<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*{Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()}
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High bandwidth usage ( > {$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}% )

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].diff()}=1)

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}",errors].min(5m)}>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}",errors].min(5m)}>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}",errors].max(5m)}<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}",errors].max(5m)}<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High error rate ( > {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Recovers when below 80% of {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} threshold

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].diff()}=1)

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].change()}<0 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()}>0 and ( {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=6 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=7 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=11 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=62 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=69 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=117 ) and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}<>2)
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].change()}>0 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].prev()}>0) or ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2)
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].diff()}=1)

trigger_prototype.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].diff()}=1)
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
trigger_prototype.description:
Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. This trigger expression works as follows: 1. Can be triggered if operations status is down. 2. {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 - user can redefine Context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down. 3. {TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1) - trigger fires only if operational status was up(1) sometime before. (So, do not fire 'ethernal off' interfaces.)
WARNING: if closed manually - won't fire again on next poll, because of .diff.

Template tooling version used: 0.30

trigger.expression: {Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent:perf_counter_en["\Processor Information(_total)\% Interrupt Time"].min(5m)}>{$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}
trigger.name: CPU interrupt time is too high (over {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. "The CPU Interrupt Time in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}%." The Processor Information\% Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. This is an easy way to identify a potential hardware failure. This should never be higher than 20%.

trigger.expression: {Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent:perf_counter_en["\Processor Information(_total)\% Privileged Time"].min(5m)}>{$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}
trigger.name: CPU privileged time is too high (over {$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. The CPU privileged time in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}%.

dependency.name: CPU interrupt time is too high (over {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
dependency.expression: {Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent:perf_counter_en["\Processor Information(_total)\% Interrupt Time"].min(5m)}>{$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}

trigger.expression: {Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent:perf_counter_en["\System\Processor Queue Length"].min(5m)}>{$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX}
trigger.name: CPU queue length is too high (over {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. The CPU Queue Length in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX}%.

trigger.expression: {Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent:system.swap.size[,pfree].min(5m)}<{$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN} and {Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent:system.swap.size[,total].last()}>0
trigger.name: High swap space usage ( less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. This trigger is ignored, if there is no swap configured

trigger.expression: {Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent:perf_counter_en["\Memory\Free System Page Table Entries"].max(5m)}<{$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN}
trigger.name: Number of free system page table entries is too low (less {$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN} for 5m)
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. The Memory Free System Page Table Entries is less than {$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN} for 5 minutes. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

trigger.name: The Memory Pages/sec is too high (over {$MEM.PAGE_SEC.CRIT.MAX} for 5m)
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. The Memory Pages/sec in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$MEM.PAGE_SEC.CRIT.MAX}. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

trigger.expression: {Template Module Windows generic by Zabbix agent:system.uptime.last()}<10m
trigger.name: Host has been restarted (uptime < 10m)
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. The device uptime is less than 10 minutes.

trigger.name: System time is out of sync (diff with Zabbix server > {$SYSTEM.FUZZYTIME.MAX}s)

trigger.expression: {Template Module Windows generic by Zabbix agent:system.hostname.diff()}=1 and {Template Module Windows generic by Zabbix agent:system.hostname.strlen()}>0
trigger.name: Systen name has changed (new name: {ITEM.VALUE})
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. System name has changed. Ack to close.
